subject: Ethics
title: Aldo Leopold's Land Ethic
description: A quick, practical guide to Aldo Leopold's Land Ethic.

hook.text: A forester spent decades killing wolves to protect deer. Then he watched a dying wolf and changed everything.

buildup.text: Aldo Leopold started as a typical conservationistâ€”nature existed to serve human needs, nothing more.

discovery.text: His 1949 'land ethic' proposed that soil, water, plants, and animals all deserve moral consideration.

twist.text: Leopold argued we shouldn't ask 'is this land useful?' but 'is this land healthy?'

climax.text: A thing is right when it preserves the integrity and beauty of the biotic community. Wrong when otherwise.

punchline.text: Leopold made dirt a moral patient. That changed everything.

quiz.question: What did Aldo Leopold's land ethic argue about nature's moral standing?
options: Nature only matters when it benefits humans economically
Soil, water, plants, and animals all deserve moral consideration
Only endangered species deserve ethical protection
